captions.text:
This wouldn't be a youtube channel without
a cat video - so without further ado, we present:
Schrodinger's cat.

I'm sure you've heard some version of this
famous thought experiment: you put a cat in

a bunker with some unstable gunpowder that
has a 50% chance of blowing up in the next

minute, and 50% chance of doing nothing. [the
gunpowder is Einstein's version - Schrodinger

preferred poisonous gas] So until we look
in the bunker, we don't know whether the cat

is dead or alive, and when we do look, it
is either dead or alive. But if we repeat

the experiment enough times with enough cats
and bunkers and gunpowder, we'll see that

half the time kitty survives, and half the
time kitty goes bye-bye. The quantum mechanical

interpretation is that before we look, the
cat is in a superposition - it's both dead

AND alive - and our act of looking forces
nature's decision. So our curiosity kills
the cat.

But what about the cat's perspective? Well,
the cat either sees the gunpowder explode,

or not – so inside the bunker we actually
have these two possibilities: "the powder

exploded and the cat saw it explode" or "the
powder didn't explode and the cat didn't see

it explode". There's no option: "the powder
exploded and the cat didn't see it explode"

- so the cat's reality becomes entangled with
the outcome of the experiment! And it's our

observation of the experiment that forces
nature to "collapse" to one option or the
other.

But we're like the cat, too – either the
cat dies and we see it dead, or the cat lives

and we see it alive – so who's observing
us to force nature to "collapse" to one reality?

Or do both possibilities happen in parallel
within a larger multiverse?

This "collapsing to one reality" problem is
one of the biggest unanswered questions in

quantum physics. So for kitty's sake, can
i has answer pleez?

comments.text:
Hi guys, I just wanted to clear this up simply for people like me and 
people from the UK who aren't so in tune and who didn't quite get it at 
first.

Imagine supporting a soccer team who was in the final of a playoff game, 
but you were on an aeroplane at the time. When you get off the aeroplane 
before you check the score, there exists 2 options. Firstly, your team has 
WON and is jubilant. Secondly your team has LOST and is despondent.

Until the moment you check the score, BOTH scenarios exist and run in 
parallel. That is it in simple terms.﻿

comments.author: Michele Hax

comments.text:
😂 Yes, Schroedinger's Cat is a classical thought experiment exploring the 
duality of existence, or the concept of an object being in a state of 
Quantum Flux (all possible outcomes exist simultaneously) until observation 
causes the collapse of the flux state into a single outcome.
The real brain tweeker is the concept that we, by the process of 
observation, actively determine the state. In other words, *if we decide 
that the cat is alive, it will be*! But only if we consciously determine 
that outcome at the moment of observation. And so, we are therefore capable 
of determining our own reality!

comments.text:
I don't like the explanation of Schrödingers Cat. The idea is to convey the 
basic thoughts of the quantum mechanics.
When I read through all these comments I can clearly figure out that the 
majority of the people can't agree with the thought that the result of an 
event is THEN determined when a human looks at it. That's not the principle 
behind quantum mechanics.

The real statement of quantum physics is, that an object has more then one 
state of being, if it isnt observed at all. But the observation can be done 
by any particle. So in case of Schrödingers Cat, it's the atoms of the cat 
that oberve themself. And all the light or any other electrical waves or 
particles that interact with another determines the state in which 
something has to be.﻿

comments.author: bipolar transition

comments.text:
Hmm... so the philosophy here is that in our mind, the answer is 
non-existent. What we, our physical selves - our 3D entities - observe is a 
wall, imaged to us in 2D, because we see in 2D. So, what does our mind see 
then? Since I believe our minds are our 2D selves, the observer's mind then 
considers both outcomes but can choose neither. It can attempt to predict, 
because it thinks, but in its reality, the cat is possibly dead and 
possibly alive, so in the mind's realm of existence, it is dead and alive 
at the same time.

So the observer's mind is not made up until it is able to receive 
information that states otherwise. It requires our senses to alter its own 
reality...

So this dilemma here... you put a cat in a bunker with the explosive 
whatever... you know it's either dead or alive, to you it's both dead and 
alive until proven otherwise, because neither have been proven not true. If 
we were 4th Dimensional beings, we would be able to "see" the cat in it's 
current state, and we would know, because we could see in the 3 dimensions. 
We could see what was on the other side of the walls.

So... the 3D beings that we are, are really just the mind of the 4D beings 
that we exist with, just as our 2D minds are within our 3D selves. So this 
logic problem exists on all dimensions.﻿

comments.author: Robert Hardy

comments.text:
Personally, I think that Schrödinger's Cat is more of an interesting 
thought experiment, not a distinct possibility.

A lot of People have been (falsely) taught that the double slit experiment 
is the Universe making a decision based on the observer, thus proving 
Schrödinger's Cat; it's not. The Universe isn't conscious. What is actually 
happening is the electron passing through the slit is simply interacting 
with the subatomic particles that make up the observer (I.E: A laser diode, 
or other quantum observational medium), thus any results observed will be 
biased by the mere presence of the observing medium. Therefore, we can 
never know... Regardless, it will always pass through one slit, or the 
other.﻿
